I miss you all terribly!

It has been almost 2 years since Celebration 3. It is now one of my fondest memories. I can still remember the drive to Indy with Brackett (aka Darth Danza) and watching the SW films on his in dash DVD. I remember the exhilaration of pulling into downtown Indy and thinking that I was going to the event I had so desperately wanted to go to the past two times. I thought it was going to be a fun few days of Star Wars geeking out.

Looking back the Star Wars stuff was unimportant. What was more fun was the people I was with. Many of them I now know are lifelong friends. The Star Wars stuff was just an excuse to get us together. We shared a common interest, but we found out that many of us shared more than just that common interest.

I smile every time I think about sitting in the line for the opening ceremonies. All these people I had only met in chat rooms and message boards were right there in front of me. It was a surreal moment. Blizz, who I had chatted with since 2000 was sitting right there taking pictures with her action figures (not to mention doing some weird other stuff with them ;)). Life was certainly good.

That week I had the pleasure to meet Brooke. I had seen her around the GS before but had never really chatted with her. Wouldn't you know it I spent more time hanging out with her than any other person there. We hit it off right away. I know if she lived closer we would still be hanging out a lot and goofing off together.

T'bone, another person I ran into on the GS back in 2000. Other than chatting in Jedinetwork every once in a while we didn't talk to much until Halo 2. We played that game so much. Lou doesn't know it but he saved me a lot of money by getting me addicted to that game. It kept me in more often than I used to. We even played the night before we were both leaving for C3, in fact I stayed up way too late because of it. He turned out to be just as good of a guy once I met him. I hope I have the pleasure of hanging out with him again. I can't wait til Halo 3 comes out so I can play some CTF with him.

Jim aka Fish I had met back in Jedinetwork days. I'm not sure how much he really remembered me, but we started chatting again before C3. That guy knew more about movies than anyone I had ever met and probably will ever meet. Maybe some day if my film stuff pans out we can work together on a film. I'm pretty sure it would be great.

Then there is the beautiful Scot, Flo! I didn't think it was possible for me to "giggle" but she made me. She is not only beautiful, but she's got a personality to boot! :P She unfortunately is in the same boat as me on not getting to go to C4, too bad I'm not in Scotland so we could sulk over a pint together.

Jeff aka Horse Head, yet another from Jedinetwork that I had wanted to meet for a while. His crazy photoshops always had me laughing back in the day. He was the guy in chat who wouldn't even mistreat the newbies, unless of course they were asking for it pretty bad. Him and his buddy Reggie have my gratitude forever for scoring us our C3 Vaders. He's also fun to drink some beer with I was really looking forward to partying with him at C4... :(

I think this might have to go into part 2 for everyone else.

I just wanted to let you know that you guys have helped create a memory I will never forget. I hope you all know that I care for you all and I hope some day we will all get to hang out together again...

Many others will be mentioned in Part 2. In fact I might say some more about these people too...who knows.

May the Force Be With You ;)

Well it is that time of year again when boredem starts to turn into a never ending party. It's summer yet again. The beginning of summer also means another thing, graduations. Every year at this time I see stories of people at their graduations getting in trouble or being thrown out for "being over exuberent" or "loud". My thing with this is, so what? Take this story for example. Kicked out for being excited about actually being allowed to graduate? Here's a little note to the faculty at schools like this. THIS IS NOT YOUR GRADUTION, IT IS YOUR STUDENTS! They are allowed to be excited about moving onto a new stage in their life. Showing emotion hurts no one, and in my opinion it makes for a hell of a better ceremony. By removing these kids all you are doing is ruining something that could've been a great memory for them. Most likely to you it won't mean anything 10 years down the road, but to them it is a memory they will never forget. I just feel like we are training our children to be mindless drones that lack anything that makes us human. Not that I don't think it would be cool to be a robot. So let's put a rigid set of rules and standards on everything so there may be no more freethinking. Let's make our school system into one giant cookie cutter that puts out the same thing every year. Hey you over there, better not celebrate accomplishing something, because what would other people think??? Here's another one Ok, so she was late (sort of, she arrived 2 minutes before the doors were supposed to be locked, but 53 minutes later than most of her classmates). I also hate it when people aren't punctual. I think it is selfish to make other people wait for you, when you have agreed upon a time. First though, let's start off by saying the girl was only 18, at that age you still have plenty of maturing to do. You can't expect high school kids to be perfect. Once again to the faculty, it isn't your graduation, it is your students. Do not deny them something they most likely looked forward to since the day they stepped into your circle of hell. I understand you are bitter and we don't pay you enough, but please try to remember that you were young once and you made mistakes or were wound up with too much energy. Throwing a student in jail because they want to experience something all their friends are going to do, isn't the right thing to do. Now I do believe there are times when you need to be calm and collected. You can't always let your emotions control you, but I don't think it should ever be forbidden. Why shouldn't we take joy in the fact that we feel like we do? Isn't this what sets us apart from all other types of animals (mind you dolphins are some cool fuckers :P). People just need to learn to use their judgement better. If it isn't hurting anyone, what is the harm? Oh well, end of that lil rant. I really do have more to say but I'd require a book to do that. Instead I will tell you of how I spent my weekend. Well folks it was filled with much beer. I went to my friend Nicole's graduation party. There was a keg and lots of cans of beer. I had way too much to drink. Luckily I had a designated driver. I had also had a few the night before at the Funny Bone. The comics there were mediocre at best, it explains why no one has really heard of them except people who are in the comedy circuit. Sunday night I almost caught myself on fire during a bonfire with some friends. Suprisinly there was no drinking involved, which makes it even worse. Luckily I was not hurt and came away only with no hair on any of my toes. If your whole foot has never been engulfed in flames I suggest you try it, it is quite a rush. I now have two days off and I am going biking later today and plan on finally getting my laundry done. I know I lead such an exciting life. Maybe I'll go up to Fox and the Hound later tonight and get my drink on. I can see if they have even ordered my new mug in yet.... As always thanks for listening.

Randomness is appreciated by few, but to those who do appreciate it, thank you. You are embracing uniqueness...and now for some random.

I am rolling over many thoughts lately. The whole situation with Danielle made me realize quite a few things.

First, why must people get so caught up in romance and think it is something out of 'The Notebook'? Not every romance is epic, and it isn't going to be picture perfect. So the first time there is one small hitch in how you think it should be going, don't freak out. People need to learn how to adapt. Not everything can be scripted and perfect. Everyone is to caught up in having things handed to them, and everything has to be perfect. Not everything is easy, and not everything will be perfect. When you set yourself up for perfect, you are doing nothing but setting yourself up for failure.

Secondly, why must people and try and make excuses for every mistake they make? Own up to your mistakes and take credit for being an ass. Everyone makes mistakes, if you insist on covering them up and making excuses don't expect me to treat you like an adult. I think a big sign of maturity is owning up to ones own mistakes. It is what you do after you own up to them that really shows if you are ready to deal with it the next time. If you "man up" and still try to make excuses for why it happened then you are still trying to pawn the blame on something besides yourself.

The funeral was this morning at 11. It was a beautiful service. The preacher made it a very personal message and while it was sad it was a message of hope. There can always be hope. Dave always thought there was when he was sick, so now we have to hope that he is in a better place.

My sister is still taking it very hard. Yesterday at the visitation she cried most of the time, but got better as every hour passed until the very end when they said it was time to leave. She wouldn't leave his side and refused to believe he was dead. :( This morning at the service there was more crying, but I think it gave her a better sense of closure than anything else has. I don't think I saw her cry at all during the lunch after the service. Then once we went back to Dave's family's house she was much better. I think all the support she is receiving from everyone has helped her a lot. She is the one taking it the hardest. 

This isn't supposed to happen! He only just turned 26, he's supposed to have more years. My sister is only 23, she isn't supposed to have had to lose someone so close already. I don't care what anyone says, this will change her forever, now all her friends and family have to see her through this period so she comes out stronger instead of bitter and downtrodden. The whole thing is just severely depressing.

Dave's family has been very good to her, in fact they were estastic when Dave proposed to her over a year ago. They were hoping Leah would be the one to shape him up since she had a good head on her shoulders. She worked with him and he got better, he was still stubborn and bullheaded, but he loved my sister and she loved him so much. I should've seen this earlier and been a little more supportive. Luckily earlier this year me and him started to get along much better. Although I was told he always liked me. I just didn't like him because of his habits. 

He had a lot of friends and left a lot of them behind. He will be missed. 

R.I.P David Allen Hellmann

So, this might be a little long or not, it really depends on how much I feel like reading. So if it gets too long let me apologize in advance.

The biggest peice of news that happened while I was away was that my sister's fiancee took a turn for the worse in his battle with cancer, they really aren't sure if he is going to make it to the new year. Although each week that goes by his chances get better for a little longer life. A couple weeks ago they were saying days to weeks, then it went to weeks to up to a year, after that it went back to trying to keep him alive til Christmas. Now we won't find out anything new til the 27th. He actually seems like he is doing a little better, he is still retaining water and such, but not to the point he was in his last chemo.

My sister isn't taking it too well, which is understandable. It's really hard to cope with something like that when someone is dying that you want to spend your whole life with, the fact that he is so young makes it that much harder. I hope she makes it through this all ok.

My second big news is the leasing of the townhouse that I am in. It's a 3 story (w/ a basement also) townhouse, it has 4 bedrooms and is about 1500 sq. ft. It is just my two buddies, Jeff and Brian, and me. We are just about all moved in now. In fact we went shopping today and spent almost $400 on groceries. I have nice racing rims and low profile tires so this happens quite often, but since we were going to evacuate in the morning this wasn't very good news. We kept filling it up with air since it was a small leak hoping it would get us out ok.

We went to bed with Katrina rating a Category 3 and we were planning to leave the next morning. What we saw when we woke up in the morning strengthened our resolve. Katrina had been upgrated to a Category 5 overnight and recorded some of the highest gusts ever on record. Not to mention it was one of the largest hurricanes ever seen it terms of area. So we tried to go to 8'o Clock early service, but the pastor was smarter than my dad and decided to leave the day before. So we left across the causeway across Lake Pontchartrain causeway (which may be destroyed I haven't heard yet). Needless to say the waves were much choppier than they had been all week. 

Contraflow was in effect, which is where they turn all the highways one way so that people can evacuate faster. This worked pretty well up until we got to McComb, MS. About 20 miles ahead they converged the traffic and it was congested. We made it up past the Big Black River about 7 miles south of Vicksburg when my tire decided to go flat. Luckily we had lived in Vicksburg for 8 years and that was where we were going to stay with friends. They came and picked us up and a tow truck took my car since I don't have a spare at the moment. Well we made it to the McIntyre's house and started to watch the devistation that was about to unfold.

We went outside this morning to survey the damage. There were trees everywhere. Limbs littered everywhere most of the roads in the south right now are not driveable. It's a really sobering scene.
